verses.text: And Joshua son of Nun sent two men secretly as spies from Shittim, saying, “Go, look over the land, especially Jericho.” And they went and entered the house of a prostitute named Rahab, and stayed there.
verses.comment: Rahab is identified as a 'prostitute' (Hebrew: zonah); no alteration.

verses.text: It was told to the king of Jericho, “Behold, men from the sons of Israel have come here tonight to search out the land.”
verses.comment: Direct translation; no significant difference.

verses.text: So the king of Jericho sent word to Rahab, saying, “Bring out the men who have come to you, who have entered your house, for they have come to search out the whole land.”
verses.comment: Maintains force of royal command; no additional changes.

verses.text: But the woman had taken the two men and hidden them. And she said, “Yes, the men came to me, but I did not know where they were from.
verses.comment: Reflects Rahab’s act and partial truth; direct rendering.

verses.text: And when the gate was about to be closed at dark, the men went out. I do not know where the men went. Pursue them quickly, for you may overtake them.”
verses.comment: Rahab’s misleading statement; no change.

verses.text: But she had brought them up to the roof and hidden them under stalks of flax that she had laid in order on the roof.
verses.comment: Details about hiding; ‘stalks of flax’ is explicit.

verses.text: So the men pursued after them on the road to the Jordan as far as the fords, and as soon as the pursuers had gone out, the gate was shut.
verses.comment: Road, fords, and gate closing all included; no significant changes.

verses.text: Before they lay down, she came up to them on the roof
verses.comment: Simple clause; modern readable format.

verses.text: and said to the men, “I know that the LORD has given you the land, and that the terror of you has fallen upon us, and all the inhabitants of the land melt away before you.
verses.comment: ‘Melt away’ preserves vivid Hebrew phrase.

verses.text: For we have heard how the LORD dried up the water of the Red Sea before you when you came out of Egypt, and what you did to the two kings of the Amorites who were beyond the Jordan, to Sihon and Og, whom you devoted to destruction.
verses.comment: ‘Devoted to destruction’ is literal for ‘herem’.

verses.text: And as soon as we heard it, our hearts melted, and no courage remained in any man because of you, for the LORD your God, he is God in the heavens above and on the earth beneath.
verses.comment: ‘No courage remained in any man’ preserves masculine noun from Hebrew; no gender alteration.

verses.text: Now then, please swear to me by the LORD that, as I have dealt kindly with you, you also will deal kindly with my father’s house, and give me a true sign.
verses.comment: ‘Kindly’ translates ‘hesed’ (steadfast love/kindness); no change.

verses.text: and that you will save alive my father and mother, my brothers and sisters, and all who belong to them, and deliver our lives from death.”
verses.comment: ‘Save alive’ and ‘deliver from death’ are close to original words.

verses.text: And the men said to her, “Our life for yours to die, if you do not tell this business of ours. Then when the LORD gives us the land, we will deal kindly and faithfully with you.”
verses.comment: ‘Our life for yours to die’ literally reflects Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: Then she let them down by a rope through the window, for her house was built into the city wall, so that she lived in the wall.
verses.comment: ‘Lived in the wall’ matches Hebrew phrase; historical note.

verses.text: And she said to them, “Go to the hill country, lest the pursuers encounter you; hide yourselves there three days until the pursuers have returned; then afterward you may go your way.”
verses.comment: ‘Three days’ preserved; matches Hebrew.

verses.text: The men said to her, “We will be released from this oath you made us swear, unless you do the following:
verses.comment: ‘Released from oath’ accurately reflects Hebrew.

verses.text: Behold, when we enter the land, you must tie this scarlet cord in the window through which you let us down, and gather your father and mother, your brothers, and all your father’s household into your house.
verses.comment: Scarlet cord details; matches original language.

verses.text: If anyone goes outside the doors of your house into the street, his blood will be on his own head, and we will be innocent. But anyone who is with you in the house, his blood will be on our head if a hand is laid on him.
verses.comment: ‘Blood on own head’ is a Hebrew idiom indicating responsibility.

verses.text: But if you tell this business of ours, then we will be released from the oath you made us swear.”
verses.comment: Direct translation of oath condition.

verses.text: And she said, “According to your words, so be it.” Then she sent them away, and they departed, and she tied the scarlet cord in the window.
verses.comment: Narrative actions preserved: agreement, cord, and departure.

verses.text: They went and came to the hill country and stayed there three days, until the pursuers returned. The pursuers searched all along the road but did not find them.
verses.comment: ‘Hill country’ and search details mirror Hebrew syntax.

verses.text: Then the two men returned. They came down from the hills, crossed over, and came to Joshua son of Nun. They told him all that had happened to them.
verses.comment: ‘Came down from the hills’ clarifies geography.

verses.text: And they said to Joshua, “Truly, the LORD has given all the land into our hands, and also all the inhabitants of the land melt away because of us.”
verses.comment: ‘Melt away’ again renders Hebrew idiom without alteration.
